labels.rationale: Strong achievement signals: tracking children against benchmarks, wanting to list accomplishments, running 'faster than ever' but wanting score-keeping. Self-direction in teaching himself upholstery independently. Stimulation in learning new skills, redesigning apartment. Power concern evident in defensiveness about status and desire for recognition.

Very strong achievement: tracking hours precisely (forty hours), detailed mastery pursuit (five hours research on 1920s veneer, three tries), knowing work was good before client saw it, wanting bigger challenges. Strong stimulation: workshop expansion explicitly to attempt harder challenges, seeking novelty in restoration complexity. Self-direction in independent learning and self-assessment. Benevolence in involving twins, teaching Emma to help measure.
